metadata.title: Letter from Murray Sheehan to Miss Marshall, October 27, 1938
metadata.creator: Murray Sheehan
metadata.description: Letter from Murray Sheehan regarding Mr. Prasobsukh Sukhsvasti's graduate records.
metadata.transcript:
[HANDWRITTEN: 1) RP. 2) The M/S - Pls note & return]
[HANDWRITTEN]

2300 KALORAMA ROAD.
WASHINGTON,D.C.

STUDENTS’ DEPARTMENT
MURRAY SHEEHAN, SUPERINTENDENT

SIAMESE LEGATION

October 27, 1958

Secretary to the President
Miami University
Oxford, Ohio

My dear Miss Marshall:

Miss Aurelia Rosser has written to say that you would like to have Mr. Prasobsukh Sukhsvasti's present address and occupation for the 1938 graduate files.

Mr. Sukhsvasti should be listed as M. C. Prasobsukh Sukhsvasti, 10 Pra Aditya Road, Bangkok, Siam. I should like again, as on previous occasions, to request that the title of "Prince" be not granted to him by Miami University, despite Mr. Sukhsvasti's own apparent wide publicity on that score. His position in Siam may be, as before, a high-school teahher, or he may now be granted a position in one of the Government offices.

Unfortunately, Miss Rosser named you only as "Miss Marshall," so I am unable to address you more fully.

Yours very truly,

[HANDWRITTEN: Murray Sheehan]

Superintendent
metadata.text_reading:
1) RP. 2) The M/S - Pls note & return.

My dear Miss Marshall: Miss Aurelia Rosser has written to say that you would like to have Mr. Prasobsukh Sukhsvasti's present address and occupation for the 1938 graduate files. Mr. Sukhsvasti should be listed as M. C. Prasobsukh Sukhsvasti, 10 Pra Aditya Road, Bangkok, Siam. I should like again, as on previous occasions, to request that the title of "Prince" be not granted to him by Miami University, despite Mr. Suchsvasti's own apparent wide publicity on that score. His position in Siam may be, as before, a high-school teahher, or he may now be granted a position on one of the Government offices. Unfortunately, Miss Rosser named you only as "Miss Marshall," so I am unable to address you more fully. Yours very truly, Murray Sheehan, Superintendent.

metadata.description: Letter discussing travel plans and a past visit to Oxford.
metadata.transcript:
October 19, 1937

Mr. Kiyoshi Tomizawa
1826 Bush Street
San Francisco, California

My dear Tomizawa:

All summer and fall the Upham family have been planning a winter vacation which would take the shape of a trip around the world. In spite of many discouragements we are still hopeful of carrying out our plans. If we do, we shall sail from San Francisco at noon on Saturday, November 13, using the President Hoover of the Dollar Line. Of course these ships do not now touch at any Chinese ports, but we are still hopeful that we may be allowed to land at Yokohama and spend a number of days in Japan. For that reason in particular I should enjoy having opportunity for a chat with you either at the pier or shortly before we sail. Since our time is limited we do not expect to reach San Francisco before Friday night. We shall probably stay overnight at the Sir Francis Drake Hotel.

We all enjoyed your visit to Oxford in June quite as much as I suspect you did. You reestablished many warm friendships here, and we are all proud of the work you are doing.

With all good wishes,

Very truly yours,

President

correspondents: His Excellency, the Minister from Siam
metadata.description: Letter concerning Prasob Sukhvasth's academic performance and plans.
metadata.transcript:
October 20, 1937

His Excellency, the Minister from Siam
Siamese Legation
Washington, D. C.

Dear Sir:

Prasob Sukhvasth, who has returned to Miami University this fall to continue his college course here, has asked me to write you regarding the record and impression he has made on our campus.

During his earlier residence with us we all came to think very highly of him, both on account of his natural ability and because of the determination with which he went to work to improve upon his record in the east and to profit by the educational opportunities here. Except for his wider experience he was just another Miami student, unassuming, dependable, and interested in what life here had to offer. He did first class work in his studies and made many friends among students and faculty. We have all been delighted to have him return to us this year.

There is every indication that the young man has entered upon his work this fall with the same fine spirit he manifested before. In the interval he has had added experience in teaching and in newspaper work, so that he has more definite objectives than before. His idea of continuing here until he has completed work for the master's degree seems to me entirely sound, since he will have slightly more than enough credits for the A. B. degree at Commencement time in June, and can qualify for the master's degree by the middle of the next college year, about February 1, 1939. I am sure that you may count upon him to do what he undertakes and fulfill all obligations.

Respectfully yours,

President
metadata.text_reading: October 20, 1937 His Excellency, the Minister from Siam Siamese Legation Washington, D. C. During his earlier residence with us we all came to think very highly of him, both on account of his natural ability and because of the determination with which he went to work to improve upon his record in the east and to profit by the educational opportunities here. Except for his wider experience he was just another Miami student, unassuming, dependable, and interested in what life here had to offer. He did first class work in his studies and made many friends among students and faculty. We have all been delighted to have him return to us this year. There is every indication that the young man has entered upon his work this fall with the same fine spirit he manifested before. In the interval he has had added experience in teaching and in newspaper work, so that he has more definite objectives than before. His idea of continuing here until he has completed work for the master's degree seems to me entirely sound, since he will have slightly more than enough credits for the A. B. degree at Commencement time in June, and can qualify for the master's degree by the middle of the next college year, about February 1, 1939. I am sure that you may count upon him to do what he undertakes and fulfill all obligations. Respectfully yours, President

metadata.creator: Unknown
metadata.description: Letter regarding a sabbatical trip around the world with plans to visit Cairo, Luxor, and Jerusalem.
metadata.transcript:
October 20, 1937

President William M. Jardine
University of Wichita
Wichita, Kansas

My dear Jardine:

You may recall that when I was in your home last June I indicated with very little confidence that the Uphams were hoping to utilize a sabbatical leave for winter vacation this year for a trip around the world. One obstacle after another seems to arise to prevent this, but we are still pushing ahead with our plans and have engaged passage on a boat leaving San Francisco November 13. Of course we shall have to detour around China, and perhaps a few other places, but we are due to reach Cairo about February 14 and make that our headquarters until the end of February. We have no detailed plans for those two weeks but expect to make the trip to Luxor and also to Jerusalem.

I am wondering if in the light of your experience and acquaintance there you would have any suggestions you would care to offer or would indicate any people whom we ought to see. I am told that this is the busiest time of the year there, and well understand how that would be so. If only you and your family were located there once more, this part of our trip would be a real holiday. As it is, we shall be just some other American tourists.

I am not letting much publicity out in regard to this winter trip, because however valuable it may be for professors to enjoy sabbatical travel, the public hardly approves of presidents doing such wasteful things.

With all good wishes,

Very truly yours,

President
metadata.text_reading: October 20, 1937 President William M. Jardine University of Wichita Wichita, Kansas My dear Jardine: You may recall that when I was in your home last June I indicated with very little confidence that the Uphams were hoping to utilize a sabbatical leave for winter vacation this year for a trip around the world. One obstacle after another seems to arise to prevent this, but we are still pushing ahead with our plans and have engaged passage on a boat leaving San Francisco November 13. Of course we shall have to detour around China, and perhaps a few other places, but we are due to reach Cairo about February 14 and make that our headquarters until the end of February. We have no detailed plans for those two weeks but expect to make the trip to Luxor and also to Jerusalem. I am wondering if in the light of your experience and acquaintance there you would have any suggestions you would care to offer or would indicate any people whom we ought to see. I am told that this is the busiest time of the year there, and well understand how that would be so. If only you and your family were located there once more, this part of our trip would be a real holiday. As it is, we shall be just some other American tourists. I am not letting much publicity out in regard to this winter trip, because however valuable it may be for professors to enjoy sabbatical travel, the public hardly approves of presidents doing such wasteful things. With all good wishes, Very truly yours, President

metadata.title: Oxford Page Two - Dr. Upham Planning Trip to Japan
metadata.description: Article discussing Dr. A. H. Upham's planned trip to Japan and related duties.
metadata.transcript:
PAGE TWO

Ralph McGinnis, correspondent, phone Oxford 256-J or 560-L. Miss Jean Van Ausdall, society and personals, phone Oxford 596. News items may be left at Hosack’s Studio. J. C. Byrne Drug company, business agent for the Journal-News Phone Oxford 41 for subscriptions and advertisements.

DR. UPHAM AND FAMILY PLANNING TRIP TO JAPAN

To Leave San Francisco Next Week For Voyage: Duties On Campus Placed In Hands Of A. K. Morris

Special To The Journal-News. Oxford, Nov. 16. Dr. A. H. Upham, Miami president, Mrs. Upham, and daughter, Peggy, will leave this week for a winter vacation which will be in the nature of a Sabbatical leave.

The Uphams plan to leave San Francisco early next week and will visit Japan, Hong Kong, the Philippines, Java, India, Egypt, and the Mediterranean countries, returning via New York.

Dr. Upham will study educational methods in foreign universities and will visit Miami alumni living abroad. They will be met in Honolulu by Mrs. W. H. Shideler, and later will meet Dr. Shideler, who is touring the world, in Bombay.

The Uphams plan to renew old acquaintances among Miami alumni now living in Japan, the Philippines, and other countries.

Dr. Upham returned to Miami in 1927 after an absence of eight years as president of the University of Idaho. A. K. Morris, vice president, will act for him in his absence.

A.A.U.W. Arrang

Oxford Business Notices

FOR SALE—Electric stove in good condition, Apply McGreevy Dairy and Ice Co., Dixie highway. 79-2r

filed in prob... estate, estima... his children... Covert died... November 7...

metadata.creator: President
metadata.description: Letter discussing travel plans and itinerary in Japan.
metadata.transcript:
October 19, 1937

Mr. Koichi Hasegawa  
57 Naka 1 Chome  
Sonezaki, Kitaku  
Osaka, Japan  

My dear Hasegawa:  

In spite of many discouragements the Upham family is still planning quite definitely a winter vacation which will take the form of a trip around the world. We shall have to be detoured around China, but we still have every assurance that your country will be open to visitors and that we shall have every opportunity to get around. I have heard from Dr. Shideler, who has been in Japan until very recently and who I believe saw you during his visit there. We would be glad also to see you sometime and some place which proves to be convenient for you during our all too limited stay in the country.  

Our present plan is to reach Yokohama on the President Hoover on the morning of Saturday, November 27. We have reservations at the Imperial Hotel in Tokyo for several days. We are to reach Kioto Wednesday afternoon, December 1, and will be at the Miyako Hotel there. We plan to sail from Kobe Sunday, December 5. I am writing you these details so that it may be easier for you to establish contact with us, and not with the thought that you should feel any obligation whatever to show us around or do things for us. We have arranged a rather busy itinerary with the American Express, and hope that the rather unusual conditions now prevailing will not interfere too seriously with what we should like to do.  

With all good wishes,  

Very truly yours,  

President

We shall have to be detoured around China, but we still have every assurance that your country will be open to visitors and that we shall have every opportunity to get around. I have heard from Dr. Shideler, who has been in Japan until very recently and who I believe saw you during his visit there. I am writing you these details so that it may be easier for you to establish contact with us, and not with the thought that you should feel any obligation whatever to show us around or do things for us. We have arranged a rather busy itinerary with the American Express, and hope that the rather unusual conditions now prevailing will not interfere too seriously with what we should like to do. With all good wishes, Very truly yours, President

metadata.creator: A. H. Upham
metadata.description: Foreword discussing Thai dancing and cultural exchange at Miami University written by A. H. Upham.
metadata.transcript:
FO REWARD

Dancing, like music, is an art that has no boundaries of race and language. This little book by a native of Thailand has grown out of a voluntary class in ball-room dancing conducted by him for a typical group of American students. He perfected his art in England. His pupils have never witnessed the subtle posturing of Siamese dancers or heard the temple-bells that still echo in his ears. But they appreciate and profit by the added grace and rhythm and sense of refined beauty he has brought with him from other shores.

Swasdi Nitibhon and the little group of other young men from Thailand who have chosen to live and work for a time among us are very welcome here at Miami University. They have sent our imaginations questing half way around the world. At the same time, with their American nicknames, their interest in our sports and recreations, and their ability to show us up in the classroom, they have made us realize how much all students everywhere have in common. We frankly admit that one of them can effectively teach us to dance our own dances.

A. H. Upham
metadata.text_reading: Dancing, like music, is an art that has no boundaries of race and language. This little book by a native of Thailand has grown out of a voluntary class in ball-room dancing conducted by him for a typical group of American students. He perfected his art in England. His pupils have never witnessed the subtle posturing of Siamese dancers or heard the temple-bells that still echo in his ears. But they appreciate and profit by the added grace and rhythm and sense of refined beauty he has brought with him from other shores. Swasdi Nitibhon and the little group of other young men from Thailand who have chosen to live and work for a time among us are very welcome here at Miami University. They have sent our imaginations questing half way around the world. At the same time, with their American nicknames, their interest in our sports and recreations, and their ability to show us up in the classroom, they have made us realize how much all students everywhere have in common. We frankly admit that one of them can effectively teach us to dance our own dances. A. H. Upham

metadata.title: College Aid Letter #4
metadata.creator: Federal Security Agency, National Youth Administration for Ohio
correspondents: Presidents of Ohio Colleges and Universities
metadata.description: Letter requesting information for the NYA College and Graduate Aid Program.
metadata.transcript:
Federal Security Agency

NATIONAL YOUTH ADMINISTRATION FOR OHIO

Hoster Bldg-
Columbus, Ohio

November 8, 1939

COLLEGE AID LETTER #4

TO; Presidents of Ohio Colleges and Universities

The Washington office of the National Youth Administration

has requested a report on institution participation in the

NYA College and Graduate Aid Program, including the following information:

1. The institution's total enrollment as of November 1, 1939.
2. The number of Negro students enrolled.
3. The total number of NYA applications received.
4. The number of applications which the institution has approved or is planning to approve for NYA Aid.
5. Institutions which have approved Negro applicants are requested to indicate the type of work to which they have been assigned.

Will you, therefore, kindly furnish us with this information, and as soon as possible, on the enclosed form? We shall appreciate receiving your report before November 17, 1939.

Sincerely yours,

S. Burns Weston
State Administrator

By: [HANDWRITTEN: Harry E. Rabe]
Harry E. Rabe, Assistant Director Work Projects Division

The institution's total enrollment as of November 1, 1939. 2. The number of Negro students enrolled. 3. The total number of NYA applications received. 4. The number of applications which the institution has approved or is planning to approve for NYA Aid. 5. Institutions which have approved Negro applicants are requested to indicate the type of work to which they have been assigned. Will you, therefore, kindly furnish us with this information, and as soon as possible, on the enclosed form? We shall appreciate receiving your report before November 17, 1939. Sincerely yours, S. Burns Weston State Administrator By: Harry E. Rabe Harry E. Rabe, Assistant Director Work Projects Division

metadata.description: Letter from university president to Mr. Murray Sheehan regarding admission of a student from Thailand.
metadata.transcript:
September 8, 1941

Mr. Murray Sheehan
Monsoonhurst 59
Glouchester, Massachusetts
Dear Murray:

Replying to your letter of September 6, I can assure you that we shall be pleased to admit Karoon Geangadmonying to Miami University as a freshman.

While of course we know nothing of the University you mention in Bangkok or of its entrance examinations, the other boys from Thailand have made such a good record here that we do not hesitate.

Freshman Week begins with a convocation next Sunday evening, September 14, but we can hold a room for him a little longer if necessary. We are trying to squeeze him into one of the freshman dormitories.

Cordially yours,

President
metadata.text_reading: September 8, 1941 Mr. Murray Sheehan Monsoonhurst 59 Glouchester, Massachusetts Dear Murray: Replying to your letter of September 6, I can assure you that we shall be pleased to admit Karoon Geangadmonying to Miami University as a freshman. While of course we know nothing of the University you mention in Bangkok or of its entrance examinations, the other boys from Thailand have made such a good record here that we do not hesitate. Freshman Week begins with a convocation next Sunday evening, September 14, but we can hold a room for him a little longer if necessary. We are trying to squeeze him into one of the freshman dormitories. Cordially yours, President

metadata.description: Typed letter discussing potential commencement speakers and international relations.
metadata.transcript:
November 19, 1941

Mr. Murray Sheehan
Royal Thai Legation
2300 Kalorama Road
Washington, D. C.

Dear Murray:

I have just now got around to the problem of finding speakers for our Commencement exercises next June. Naturally I am greatly attracted by your suggestion that there is again a minister from Thai in Washington who would qualify in every way as our speaker on the regular Commencement program. I have only two reservations which are quite obvious: one, that for some reason or other this man also may be recalled before our Commencement date; the other, that international friendships in the Pacific area may crack all to pieces before that time so that there may be no Thailand minister in Washington at all. However, I am willing to take chances on these contingencies. There is a third difficulty in which I know you can help me. That is, my utter inability to pronounce any of these Siamese names correctly in public.

Seriously, I should be glad to have you extend our invitation to the Minister to deliver the Commencement address to the graduates of Miami University on the morning of Monday, June 8, 1942, which is our regular Commencement date. If he will arrange to undertake this responsibility, I shall hope of course that you may find it convenient to escort him out here and enjoy with him the Commencement atmosphere that always characterizes Miami University.

I had hoped for an occasion which would take me to Washington before this time. Unfortunately for me, the annual meeting of the National Association of State Universities was changed from Washington to Chicago because of the difficulty of accommodating the Association in any Washington hotel.

We greatly miss some of our friends among the Thailand boys who were with us last year. Those who are here at the present time, however, are giving an excellent account of themselves.

With all good wishes,

Very truly yours,

President

[HANDWRITTEN: President]

metadata.title: Letter from M.R. Seni Pramoj to A.H. Upham, February 28, 1942
metadata.creator: M.R. Seni Pramoj
metadata.description: A letter from M.R. Seni Pramoj regarding the cancellation of a meeting due to the war.
metadata.transcript:
No. 192/2485

Mr. A.H. Upham,
President of Miami University,
Oxford, Ohio.

My dear President Upham,

Thank you for your letter of February 4th and for your offer to
give accommodation to the annual meeting of Thai students.

I much regret that, owing to the War, we shall have to cancel our
usual Students' Meeting this year and we shall therefore be unable to
avail ourselves of the hospitality which you have so kindly extended
on behalf of Miami University. I trust, however, that, at some future date and under happier circumstances, it will be possible to bring our students
to your campus.

Yours very truly,
[HANDWRITTEN: M.R. Seni Pramoj]

M.R. Seni Pramoj
Minister for Thailand.
metadata.text_reading: No. 192/2485 Mr. A.H. Upham, President of Miami University, Oxford, Ohio. My dear President Upham, Thank you for your letter of February 4th and for your offer to give accommodation to the annual meeting of Thai students. I much regret that, owing to the War, we shall have to cancel our usual Students' Meeting this year and we shall therefore be unable to avail ourselves of the hospitality which you have so kindly extended on behalf of Miami University. I trust, however, that, at some future date and under happier circumstances, it will be possible to bring our students to your campus. Yours very truly, M.R. Seni Pramoj M.R. Seni Pramoj Minister for Thailand.

metadata.title: Letter from President to Murray Sheehan, May 26, 1942
metadata.description: Letter discussing Commencement attendance and reservations for Murray Sheehan.
metadata.transcript:
May 26, 1942

Mr. Murray Sheehan
Royal Thai Legation
2300 Kalorama Road
Washington, D. C.

Dear Murray:

I am delighted to know that you are coming on for Commencement. We shall all be glad to see you and I think you will find yourself very comfortable in David Swing Hall where we are making a reservation for you.

It is too bad that we cannot have at least one boy from Theiland in the graduating class while you are here, particularly since we were unable to secure the Minister as our speaker.

Cordially yours,

President
metadata.text_reading: May 26, 1942 Mr. Murray Sheehan Royal Thai Legation 2300 Kalorama Road Washington, D. C. Dear Murray: I am delighted to know that you are coming on for Commencement. We shall all be glad to see you and I think you will find yourself very comfortable in David Swing Hall where we are making a reservation for you. It is too bad that we cannot have at least one boy from Theiland in the graduating class while you are here, particularly since we were unable to secure the Minister as our speaker. Cordially yours, President

metadata.title: Letter from Royal Thai Legation to President A. H. Upham, June 2, 1942
metadata.creator: Royal Thai Legation, Students' Department
metadata.description: A letter from the Royal Thai Legation's Students' Department to President A. H. Upham of Miami University, expressing gratitude and admiration for the university's work.
metadata.transcript:
ROYAL THAI LEGATION STUDENTS’ DEPARTMENT
2300 KALORAMA ROAD WASHINGTON,D.C.

June 2, 1942

President A. H. Upham
Miami University
Oxford, Ohio

Dear President Upham:

Just a line, upon my return to the Legation, to thank you for the many courtesies which were shown to me while I was at the University, and to tell you again how proud I am of the wonderful work which you are doing there. There is a charm and a dignity about the place which I had never so thoroughly felt before. If only I could now be looking backward to the pleasure of having been the agency through whom you secured yesterday's Commencement speaker, my cup would indeed be running over. I shall still hope in that direction!

Kindest regards to Mrs. Upham and yourself.

Sincerely yours,

[HANDWRITTEN: Murray Stickham]

Upham Miami University Oxford, Ohio Dear President Upham: Just a line, upon my return to the Legation, to thank you for the many courtesies which were shown to me while I was at the University, and to tell you again how proud I am of the wonderful work which you are doing there. There is a charm and a dignity about the place which I had never so thoroughly felt before. If only I could now be looking backward to the pleasure of having been the agency through whom you secured yesterday's Commencement speaker, my cup would indeed be running over. I shall still hope in that direction! Kindest regards to Mrs. Upham and yourself. Sincerely yours, Murray Stickham

metadata.title: Letter from C. V. Hibbard to President A. H. Upham, February 21, 1944
metadata.creator: C. V. Hibbard
metadata.publisher: National Japanese American Student Relocation Council
metadata.description: Letter regarding the deferment of Nisei students in higher education as part of the National Roster of Scientific and Specialized Personnel.
metadata.transcript:
NATIONAL JAPANESE AMERICAN STUDENT RELOCATION COUNCIL

1201 Chestnut Street, Philadelphia 7, Pa.
RITtenhouse 9372

John W. Nason, National Chairman C. V. Hibbard, National Director

February 21, 1944

President A. H. Upham
Miami University
Oxford, Ohio

Dear President Upham:

The War Manpower Commission in conjunction with the Selective Service System has recently changed the basis for the deferment of undergraduate students in Engineering, Physics, Chemistry, and similar subjects. Each college or university now has a quota assigned to it.

It has come to our attention that certain institutions are recommending Nisei students for deferment in their quotas. You may be interested in the statement of Dean Everett L. Hunt of Swarthmore College.

"We are recommending our Japanese-American boys to the National Roster of Scientific and Specialized Personnel for deferment as engineers or chemists. They have outstanding records and certainly deserve this deferment. I am not sure that the western draft boards will accept the recommendation of the National Roster on this, as I understand they have been ordered to reclassify all the 4-C boys.

"I want to assure you of our appreciation of the excellent qualities of these boys, and of our intention to do all we can to enable them to finish their training under the same terms as are given to outstanding scientific students of any other race or group."

Nisei students should not, of course, be given preferential treatment. I do hope, however, that they will be given consideration when you draw up the lists for your quotas.

Yours sincerely,

[HANDWRITTEN: C. V. Hibbard]

C. V. Hibbard, Director

Each college or university now has a quota assigned to it. It has come to our attention that certain institutions are recommending Nisei students for deferment in their quotas. You may be interested in the statement of Dean Everett L. Hunt of Swarthmore College. "We are recommending our Japanese-American boys to the National Roster of Scientific and Specialized Personnel for deferment as engineers or chemists. They have outstanding records and certainly deserve this deferment. I am not sure that the western draft boards will accept the recommendation of the National Roster on this, as I understand they have been ordered to reclassify all the 4-C boys. "I want to assure you of our appreciation of the excellent qualities of these boys, and of our intention to do all we can to enable them to finish their training under the same terms as are given to outstanding scientific students of any other race or group." Nisei students should not, of course, be given preferential treatment. I do hope, however, that they will be given consideration when you draw up the lists for your quotas. Yours sincerely, C. V. Hibbard C. V. Hibbard, Director

metadata.creator: Harold V. Lucas
metadata.description: Letter of recommendation for Wing Kong Chong.
metadata.transcript:
[HANDWRITTEN: Copy]

MIAMI UNIVERSITY 
OXFORD, OHIO

OFFICE OF THE PRESIDENT

April 24, 1940

President
Miami University
Oxford, Ohio

Dear Sir:

It has come to my attention that a personal note
from me might well be added to your file dealing with the
character and person of one of your students Wing Kong Chong
who, I understand, hopes to be graduated from your university
in 1940 with intention of returning to Hawaii to enter the
Department of Public Instruction as a teacher here. I am
very pleased to send this word of testimony concerning Mr.
Chong whom I have known for the past eight years. While I am
not qualified to speak for his scholastic ability or capacity
I do feel that I know enough of him and his brothers and sisters
to say definitely that he is the type of young man we are hoping
more and more will enter the public school system here.

I knew Wing Kong when he was in High School and during a summer
damp I came to know him even better. His character, I believe,
is above reproach. His willingness to be helpful and his leadership
even as a boy was very definitely an asset to the camp. If, during
his years on the mainland, he has continued on the path I knew him to
follow, I am sure he will be a splendid teacher and friend to youth.

Very cordially yours,

Harold V. Lucas,
GENERAL SECRETARY,[YMCA] [HANDWRITTEN]
metadata.text_reading: Copy MIAMI UNIVERSITY OXFORD, OHIO OFFICE OF THE PRESIDENT April 24, 1940 President Miami University Oxford, Ohio Dear Sir: It has come to my attention that a personal note from me might well be added to your file dealing with the character and person of one of your students Wing Kong Chong who, I understand, hopes to be graduated from your university in 1940 with intention of returning to Hawaii to enter the Department of Public Instruction as a teacher here. I am very pleased to send this word of testimony concerning Mr. Chong whom I have known for the past eight years. While I am not qualified to speak for his scholastic ability or capacity I do feel that I know enough of him and his brothers and sisters to say definitely that he is the type of young man we are hoping more and more will enter the public school system here. I knew Wing Kong when he was in High School and during a summer damp I came to know him even better. His character, I believe, is above reproach. His willingness to be helpful and his leadership even as a boy was very definitely an asset to the camp. If, during his years on the mainland, he has continued on the path I knew him to follow, I am sure he will be a splendid teacher and friend to youth. Very cordially yours, Harold V. Lucas, GENERAL SECRETARY,YMCA
metadata.generated_title: Letter from Harold V. Lucas to President, Miami University, April 24, 1940

metadata.title: Financial assistance given to students and trainees from China
metadata.description: Document discussing financial assistance and admission of Chinese nationals to American educational institutions.
metadata.transcript:
[HANDWRITTEN: F13]
20 September 1945

Financial assistance given to students and trainees from China.
Admission of Chinese nationals to American colleges and universities.

The American Ambassador to China has made the following request concerning the above two subjects:

"It would be helpful in the handling of the visa applications of Chinese students and trainees proceeding to the United States if the Department could make known as widely as possible to colleges and universities, special bodies administering scholarship funds such as the China Institute, and to American business organizations accepting Chinese as trainees, that advice of the grant of scholarships, fellowships, stipends and other financial assistance, should be sent directly to the Embassy or to the consular office of the district in which the applicant resides and that advice furnished should be as specific as possible in regard to the amount of such assistance. This is necessary in order to have some assurance of the authenticity of the information and of the adequacy of the financial assistance.

"It would be helpful if colleges and universities could be asked to send their notices of admittance directly to the visa issuing office and to make the admittance of students absolute and not conditional upon the presentation of satisfactory credentials as frequently is the case."

It should be noted that 4(e) visas may not be given when admission certificates are conditional.
metadata.text_reading: F13 20 September 1945 Financial assistance given to students and trainees from China. Admission of Chinese nationals to American colleges and universities. The American Ambassador to China has made the following request concerning the above two subjects: "It would be helpful in the handling of the visa applications of Chinese students and trainees proceeding to the United States if the Department could make known as widely as possible to colleges and universities, special bodies administering scholarship funds such as the China Institute, and to American business organizations accepting Chinese as trainees, that advice of the grant of scholarships, fellowships, stipends and other financial assistance, should be sent directly to the Embassy or to the consular office of the district in which the applicant resides and that advice furnished should be as specific as possible in regard to the amount of such assistance. This is necessary in order to have some assurance of the authenticity of the information and of the adequacy of the financial assistance. "It would be helpful if colleges and universities could be asked to send their notices of admittance directly to the visa issuing office and to make the admittance of students absolute and not conditional upon the presentation of satisfactory credentials as frequently is the case." It should be noted that 4(e) visas may not be given when admission certificates are conditional.

metadata.title: Offer of Scholarship for Korean Student
metadata.description: Document offering scholarship opportunities at Miami University for Korean students.
metadata.transcript:
OFFER OF SCHOLARSHIP FOR KOREAN STUDENT

Name of college offering opportunity -- Miami University
Address -- Oxford, Ohio

HOME OPPORTUNITY OFFERED
Room on campus in University housing.
Local group providing expense -- Foreign Student Committee.
Meal provided at dormitory.
Local group providing meals -- Foreign Student Committee.
Clothing and living expense provided by Kappa Phi Sorority and Wesley Foundation.
Books and incidental college expenses paid by Foreign Student Committee.
Provisions for vacation and holiday periods -- Foreign Student Committee.

STUDY OPPORTUNITY OFFERED
Scholarship offered to cover tuition.
Conditions of scholarship -- read and speak English.
Field of study -- Arts and Science.
One year scholarship with possible renewal.

Student Selected -- Bong Choi, 10-254 Yon Am-Dong, Seoul, Korea.
We certify that this foreign student will not displace an American student.

[HANDWRITTEN: Carol C. Anderson]
President of sponsoring student organization
[HANDWRITTEN: Paul F. Erwin]
Moderator of sponsoring student organization
[HANDWRITTEN: Ernest H. Hahne]
College President
